{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3556621,"name":"Chris ","username":"Cjackson1300","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cjackson1300/{size}/254907_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-13T23:34:06.202Z","cooked":"

Help! We could really use some programming help. We can get our robot to climb but as soon as we disable, at the buzzer, it drops.

Is there a line in code to lock our motors? At the buzzer?

Thank you so much for any and all of your help

Not a programmer but are you setting your motors to brake mode? If not then you definitely should

I’m not saying this was the best way to fix it fast, but we had that issue last week and we increased our gear ratio from 400-1 to 800-1 and it held longer.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-03-13T23:39:49.999Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":312,"readers_count":311,"score":72.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495515,"topic_slug":"deep-cage-climb","display_username":"Ryan Bias","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65767,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/deep-cage-climb/495515/3","reactions":[{"id":"open_mouth","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3556630,"name":"","username":"iz_en_zi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/iz_en_zi/{size}/226207_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-13T23:43:17.862Z","cooked":"

The best way to do this is by adding a ratcheting wrench to your mechanism, if it uses a hex shaft. Attaching one too it will and securing it will prevent the motor from backdriving. Beyond putting your motors in brake mode (which may help a bit), this mainly needs to be a hardware fix.

We disassembled it to put a ratchet gear box on it sadly. Wasn’t sustainable only did it for 3-4 matches

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-03-13T23:46:27.112Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":237,"readers_count":236,"score":47.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495515,"topic_slug":"deep-cage-climb","display_username":"Ryan Bias","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":19235,"username":"Skyehawk","name":"Skye Leake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65767,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/deep-cage-climb/495515/7","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3556637,"name":"Jonathan Z","username":"Jono37","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/f05b48/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-13T23:49:56.626Z","cooked":"

As others have suggested, the easiest way is to put your climber motor into ‘brake mode’. This isn’t like the brakes on a car, which will hold the climber in place, but it will make it harder to turn the motor.

That means after the buzzer, your robot will drop slower, hopefully slow enough to still be off the floor by the end of the 3-second count. This will ultimately depend on your mechanical setup though.

For reference, with a 45kg robot climbing on a rope wound around a 1/2" hex shaft, we ran a Kraken at 25:1 and it easily stayed up for the 3 seconds.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-03-13T23:49:56.626Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":227,"readers_count":226,"score":45.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495515,"topic_slug":"deep-cage-climb","display_username":"Jonathan Z","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28207,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Danger Captain"},"post_url":"/t/deep-cage-climb/495515/8","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3556684,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-14T01:17:25.221Z","cooked":"
Cjackson1300:

Is there a line in code to lock our motors? At the buzzer?

Just so you understand why nobody is giving you this (other than “brake mode”):

At the buzzer, all outputs on the robot go to a disabled state. No motors are energized. So gravity takes over, unless there’s some resistance.

Brake mode essentially shorts the motor to itself, which causes it to resist motion when not energized. It can still move, which is where the “more reduction” and “ratchet” calls are coming from–those reduce the torque going to the motor shaft to something it can actually stop, or lock the shaft completely.

Ours has a Neo with a 300/1 gear box in brake mode. We hang for at least 5 seconds after the buzzer.

(just putting this here as nobody else has said it…)

brake mode as other has said puts resistance on the motors. You can set this via the Rev Hardware Hub, or Phoenix Tuner X (both are apps)

I encourage you to look at documentation though for more instructions!

Another option (for future designs) is a worm gear. Properly designed they can not be back-driven. Also, you can get a large (30:1 here) reduction in a single stage. Also a 90° direction change (which may or may not be helpful).

IMG_24174032×3024 1.95 MB
